newsitem.title: JAPAN: NTT Data, MCI set Internet goals.
newsitem.headline: NTT Data, MCI set Internet goals.

text.p: NTT Data Corp announced on Thursday that it aimed to have 200,000 Internet service users by the end of March 1998.
At the same news conference, MCI Communications Corp of the United States announced that it planned to boost its annual revenues from Internet services to $2 billion a year by 2000.

The two companies held a joint news conference to announce a tie-up in a new Internet dial-roaming service, which allows overseas travellers to access the Internet without contracting with a local Internet service provider.
The companies said they will start the dial-roaming service in Japan and the United States from July.
NTT Data president Tomeo Kanbayashi told reporters: "NTT Data aims to become the number one Internet service provider in Japan in the near future."
He added that the company aims to more than triple the number of users of its Internet joint venture with Softbank Corp to 200,000 by the end of next March from the current 60,000.

MCI Communications senior vice-president Vinton Cerf said the targeted annual revenues of $2 billion from Internet-related services by 2000 was expected to represent about six percent of total revenues by that date.
Kanbayashi said the tie-up between NTT Data and MCI was not directly related to plans by NTT Data's parent company Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corp to enter international phone call services.
Cerf declined to comment on a possible tie-up between the parent NTT and the company to be formed by a merger between MCI and British Telecom.

Earlier this month MCI shareholders approved the merger, which if also approved by British Telecom shareholders and regulators would create a combined company known as Concert Plc, with $40.6 billion in revenues and an eye on capturing telecommunications markets worldwide.
